In February 2013 the American Council on Education (ACE) recommended that its members provide transfer credit from a few MOOC courses, though even the universities who deliver the courses had said that they would not.<ref name=WSJ020713>{{cite news|last=Korn|first=Melissa|title=Big MOOC Coursera Moves Closer to Academic Acceptance|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887324906004578288341039095024|accessdate=8 March 2013|newspaper=[[Wall Street Journal]]|date=7 February 2013}}</ref> The [[University of Wisconsin]] offered multiple, [[Competency-based learning|competency-based]] [[Bachelor's degree|bachelor's]] and [[Master's degree|master's]] degrees starting Fall 2013, the first public university to do so on a system-wide basis. The university encouraged students to take online-courses such as MOOCs and complete assessment tests at the university to receive credit.{{citation needed|date=May 2015}} As of 2013 few students had applied for college credit for MOOC classes.{{citation needed|date=May 2015}} [[Colorado State University-Global Campus]] received no applications in the year after they offered the option.<ref name="no takers">{{cite web|last=Kolowich|first=Steve|title=A University's Offer of Credit for a MOOC Gets No Takers|url=http://chronicle.com/article/A-Universitys-Offer-of-Credit/140131/|work=Chronicle of Higher Education|accessdate=25 July 2013|date=8 July 2013}} Udacity, which is offering an online master's degree in computer science in partnership with Georgia Tech, reported in October 2013 that applications for the term starting in January 2014 were more than double the number of applications that Georgia Tech receives for its traditional program. {{cite web|last=Belkin|first=douglas|title= First-of-Its-Kind Online Master’s Draws Wave of Applicants|url=http://stream.wsj.com/story/latest-headlines/SS-2-63399/SS-2-368104/|accessdate=31 October 2013|date=30 October 2013}}</ref>
Academic Partnerships is a company that helps public universities move their courses online. According to its chairman, Randy Best, "We started it, frankly, as a campaign to grow enrollment. But 72 to 84 percent of those who did the first course came back and paid to take the second course."<ref name=NYT012313>Tamar Lewin. [https://www.nytimes.com/2013/01/23/education/public-universities-to-offer-free-online-classes-for-credit.html Public Universities to Offer Free Online Classes for Credit]. 23 January 2013</ref>
While Coursera takes a larger cut of any revenue generated – but requires no minimum payment – the not-for-profit edX has a minimum required payment from course providers, but takes a smaller cut of any revenues, tied to the amount of support required for each course.<ref>{{cite web|last=Kolowich |first=Steve |url=http://chronicle.com/article/How-EdX-Plans-to-Earn-and/137433/ |title=How EdX Plans to Earn, and Share, Revenue From Free Online Courses - Technology - The Chronicle of Higher Education |publisher=Chronicle.com |date=21 February 2013 |accessdate=30 May 2013}}</ref>
== Benefits ==
=== Improving access to Higher Education === MOOCs are regarded by many as an important tool to widen access to Higher Education (HE) for millions of people, including those in the [[Developing country|developing world]], and ultimately enhance their quality of life. MOOCs may be regarded as contributing to the democratisation of HE, not only locally or regionally but globally as well. MOOCs can help democratise content and make knowledge reachable for everyone. Students are able to access complete courses offered by universities all over the world, something previously unattainable. With the availability of affordable technologies, MOOCs increase access to an extraordinary number of courses offered by world-renowned institutions and teachers.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0024/002451/245122E.pdf|title=Making Sense of MOOCs: A Guide for Policy-Makers in Developing Countries|last=Patru|first=Mariana|last2=Balaji|first2=Venkataraman|publisher=Paris, UNESCO|year=2016|isbn=978-92-3-100157-4|location=|pages=17–18, 21–22, 24}}</ref>
=== Providing an affordable alternative to formal education === The costs of tertiary education continue to increase because institutions tend to bundle too many services. With MOOCs, some of these services can be transferred to other suitable players in the public or private sector. MOOCs are for large numbers of participants, can be accessed by anyone anywhere as long as they have an Internet connection, are open to everyone without entry qualifications and offer a full/complete course experience online for free.<ref>Mulder, F., & Jansen. D. (2015). ''MOOCs for opening up education and the OpenupEd initiative''. In C. J. Bonk, M. M. Lee, T. C. Reeves, & T. H. Reynolds (Eds.), MOOCs and open education around the world. New York, NY: Routledge.</ref><ref name=":0" />
=== Sustainable Development Goals === {{Main|Sustainable Development Goals}}
MOOCs can be seen as a form of open education offered for free through online platforms. The (initial) philosophy of MOOCs is to open up quality Higher Education to a wider audience. As such, MOOCs are an important tool to achieve Goal 4 of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development.<ref name=":0" />
=== Offers a Flexible Learning Schedule === Certain lectures, videos, and tests through MOOCs can be accessed at any time compared to scheduled class times. By allowing learners to complete their coursework in their own time, this provides flexibility to learners based on their own personal schedules.<ref name="hbr.org">{{cite web |last1=Samuel |first1=Alexandra |title=Collaborating Online Is Sometimes Better than Face-to-Face |url=https://hbr.org/2015/04/collaborating-online-is-sometimes-better-than-face-to-face |website=Harvard Business Review |accessdate=15 June 2018}}</ref><ref name=":0" />
=== Online Collaboration === The learning environments of MOOCs make it easier for learners across the globe to work together on common goals. Instead of having to physically meet one another, online collaboration creates partnerships among learners. While time zones may have an effect on the hours that learners communicate, projects, assignments, and more can be completed to incorporate the skills and resources that different learners offer no matter where they are located.<ref name="hbr.org"/><ref name=":0" />
== Challenges and criticisms ==
The MOOC Guide<ref name="MoocGuide">{{cite web | url=http://moocguide.wikispaces.com/2.+Benefits+and+challenges+of+a+MOOC | title=Benefits and Challenges of a MOOC | publisher=MoocGuide | date=7 July 2011<!-- 11:27 pm -->| accessdate=4 February 2013}}</ref> suggests six possible challenges for cMOOCs: # Relying on user-generated content can create a chaotic learning environment # [[Digital literacy]] is necessary to make use of the online materials # The time and effort required from participants may exceed what students are willing to commit to a free online course # Once the course is released, content will be reshaped and reinterpreted by the massive student body, making the course trajectory difficult for instructors to control # Participants must self-regulate and set their own goals #Language and translation barriers
These general challenges in effective MOOC development are accompanied by criticism by journalists and academics.
[[Robert Zemsky]] (2014) argues that they have passed their peak: "They came; they conquered very little; and now they face substantially diminished prospects."<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Zemsky | first1 = Robert | year = 2014 | title = With a MOOC MOOC here and a MOOC MOOC there, here a MOOC, there a MOOC, everywhere a MOOC MOOC | jstor = 10.5325/jgeneeduc.63.4.0237 | journal = Journal of General Education | volume = 63 | issue = 4| pages = 237–243 | doi=10.1353/jge.2014.0029}}</ref> Others have pointed to a backlash arising from the tiny completion rates.<ref>{{Cite web|title=What Are MOOCs Good For?|url=https://www.technologyreview.com/s/533406/what-are-moocs-good-for/|first=Pope|last=Justin|date=15 Dec 2014|publisher=MIT Technology Review|accessdate=29 March 2016}}</ref>
Some{{who|date=February 2017}} dispute that the "territorial" dimensions of MOOCs<ref name="TerritorialDimensions">{{cite web | url=http://www.insidehighered.com/blogs/globalhighered/territorial-dimensions-moocs | title=On the territorial dimensions of MOOCs | publisher=Inside Higher Ed | date=3 December 2012 | accessdate=4 February 2013 | author=Olds, Kris}}</ref> have received insufficient discussion or data-backed analysis, namely: 1. the true geographical diversity of enrolls in/completes courses; 2. the implications of courses scaling across country borders, and potential difficulties with relevance and knowledge transfer; and 3. the need for territory-specific study of locally relevant issues and needs.
Other features associated with early MOOCs, such as open licensing of content, open structure and learning goals, and community-centeredness, may not be present in all MOOC projects.<ref name="MOOC Misnomer"/>
Effects on the structure of higher education were lamented, for example, by [[Moshe Y. Vardi]], who finds an "absence of serious pedagogy in MOOCs", and indeed in all of higher education. He criticized the format of "short, unsophisticated video chunks, interleaved with online quizzes, and accompanied by social networking."{{clarify|reason=Reads like a description rather than a critique.|date=October 2013}} An underlying reason is simple cost-cutting pressures, which could hamstring the higher education industry.<ref name=Vardi>{{cite journal|last=Vardi|first=Moshe Y.|title=Will MOOCs destroy academia?|journal=Communications of the ACM|date=November 2012|volume=55|issue=11|page=5|url=http://cacm.acm.org/magazines/2012/11/156587-will-moocs-destroy-academia/fulltext|accessdate=23 April 2013|doi=10.1145/2366316.2366317}}</ref>
The changes predicted from MOOCs generated objections in some quarters. The San Jose State University philosophy faculty wrote in an open letter to Harvard University professor and MOOC teacher [[Michael Sandel]]:
{{Quote|Should one-size-fits-all vendor-designed blended courses become the norm, we fear two classes of universities will be created: one, well-funded colleges and universities in which privileged students get their own real professor; the other, financially stressed private and public universities in which students watch a bunch of video-taped lectures.<ref name="Dear Sandel">{{cite news|title=San Jose State to Michael Sandel: Keep your MOOC off our campus|url=http://www.boston.com/bostonglobe/ideas/brainiac/2013/05/san_jose_state.html|accessdate=7 May 2013|newspaper=[[Boston Globe]]|date=3 May 2013}}</ref> }}
[[Cary Nelson]], former president of the [[American Association of University Professors]] claimed that MOOCs are not a reliable means of supplying credentials, stating that "It’s fine to put lectures online, but this plan only degrades degree programs if it plans to substitute for them." Sandra Schroeder, chair of the Higher Education Program and Policy Council for the [[American Federation of Teachers]] expressed concern that "These students are not likely to succeed without the structure of a strong and sequenced academic program."<ref>{{cite web|last=Basu |first=Kaustuv |url=http://www.insidehighered.com/news/2012/05/23/faculty-groups-consider-how-respond-moocs |title=Faculty groups consider how to respond to MOOCs |publisher=Inside Higher Ed |date=23 May 2012 |accessdate=13 October 2013}}</ref>
With a 60% majority, the [[Amherst College]] faculty rejected the opportunity to work with edX based on a perceived incompatibility with their seminar-style classes and personalized feedback. Some were concerned about issues such as the "information dispensing" teaching model of lectures followed by exams, the use of multiple-choice exams and peer-grading. The [[Duke University]] faculty took a similar stance in the spring of 2013. The effect of MOOCs on second- and third-tier institutions and of creating a professorial "star system" were among other concerns.<ref name="IHE 1">{{cite web|last=Rivard|first=Ry|title=EdX Rejected|url=http://www.insidehighered.com/news/2013/04/19/despite-courtship-amherst-decides-shy-away-star-mooc-provider|publisher=Inside Higher Education|accessdate=22 April 2013|date=19 April 2013}}</ref>
At least one alternative to MOOCs has advocates: [[Distributed open collaborative courses]] ([[DOCC]]) challenge the roles of the instructor, hierarchy, money and massiveness. DOCC recognizes that the pursuit of knowledge may be achieved better by not using a centralized singular syllabus, that expertise is distributed throughout all the participants and does not just reside with one or two individuals.<ref>Scott Jaschik, [http://www.insidehighered.com/news/2013/08/19/feminist-professors-create-alternative-moocs#ixzz2duFJIkrX "Feminist Anti-MOOC"], Inside Higher Ed, 19 August 2013.</ref>
Another alternative to MOOCs is the [[Self-Paced Online Course (SPOC)]] which provides a high degree of flexibility. Students can decide on their own pace and with which session they would like to begin their studies. According to a report by [[Class Central]] founder Dhawal Shah, more than 800 self-paced courses have been available in 2015.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Shah|first1=Dhawal|title=MOOCs in 2015: Breaking Down the Numbers|url=https://www.edsurge.com/news/2015-12-28-moocs-in-2015-breaking-down-the-numbers|accessdate=28 December 2015|publisher=edSurge|date=28 December 2015}}</ref>
Although the purpose of MOOCs is ultimately to educate more people, recent criticisms include accessibility and a Westernized curriculum that lead to a failure to reach the same audiences marginalised by traditional methods.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gais|first1=Hannah|title=Is the developing world ‘MOOC’d out’?|url=http://america.aljazeera.com/opinions/2014/7/mooc-education-developingworldivyleave.html|accessdate=19 July 2014|publisher=Al Jazeera|date=17 July 2014}}</ref>
MOOCs have been criticized for a perceived lack of academic rigor as well as the monetization strategies adopted by providers. In ''MOOCs: A University Qualification in 24 Hours?'' Michael Shea writes "By offering courses that are near-impossible to fail and charging up front fees for worthless certificates, Coursera is simply running a high-tech version of the kind of scams that have been run by correspondence colleges for decades."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Shea|first1=Michael|title=MOOCs: A university qualification in 24 hours?|url=http://www.theskinny.co.uk/tech/features/moocs|accessdate=16 October 2015|publisher=The Skinny|date=25 September 2015}}</ref>
=== The experience of English Language Learners (ELLs) in MOOCs === Language of instruction is one of the major barriers that ELLs face in MOOCs. In recent estimates, almost 75% of MOOC courses are presented in the English language, however, native English speakers are a minority among the world's population.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Uchidiuno|first=Judith|last2=Ogan|first2=Amy|last3=Koedinger|first3=Kenneth R.|last4=Yarzebinski|first4=Evelyn|last5=Hammer|first5=Jessica|date=1 January 2016|title=Browser Language Preferences As a Metric for Identifying ESL Speakers in MOOCs|url=http://doi.acm.org/10.1145/2876034.2893433|journal=Proceedings of the Third (2016) ACM Conference on Learning @ Scale|series=L@S '16|location=New York, NY, USA|publisher=ACM|pages=277–280|doi=10.1145/2876034.2893433|isbn=9781450337267}}</ref> This issue is mediated by the increasing popularity of English as a global language, and therefore has more second language speakers than any other language in the world. This barrier has encouraged content developers and other MOOC stakeholders to develop content in other popular languages to increase MOOC access. However, research studies show that some ELLs prefer to take MOOCs in English, despite the language challenges, as it promotes their goals of Economic, Social, and Geographic mobility.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Uchidiuno|first=Judith|last2=Ogan|first2=Amy|last3=Yarzebinski|first3=Evelyn|last4=Hammer|first4=Jessica|date=1 January 2016|title=Understanding ESL Students' Motivations to Increase MOOC Accessibility|url=http://doi.acm.org/10.1145/2876034.2893398|journal=Proceedings of the Third (2016) ACM Conference on Learning @ Scale|series=L@S '16|location=New York, NY, USA|publisher=ACM|pages=169–172|doi=10.1145/2876034.2893398|isbn=9781450337267}}</ref> This emphasizes the need to not only provide MOOC content in other languages, but also to develop English language interventions for ELLs who participate in English MOOCs.
Areas that ELLs particularly struggle with in English MOOCs include MOOC content without corresponding visual supporting materials<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Uchidiuno|first=Judith|last2=Hammer|first2=Jessica|last3=Yarzebinski|first3=Evelyn|last4=Koedinger|first4=Kenneth R.|last5=Ogan|first5=Amy|date=1 January 2017|title=Characterizing ELL Students' Behavior During MOOC Videos Using Content Type|url=http://doi.acm.org/10.1145/3051457.3053981|journal=Proceedings of the Fourth (2017) ACM Conference on Learning @ Scale|series=L@S '17|location=New York, NY, USA|publisher=ACM|pages=185–188|doi=10.1145/3051457.3053981|isbn=9781450344500}}</ref> (e.g., an instructor narrating instruction without text support in the background), or their hesitation to participate in MOOC discussion forums.<ref name="Kulkarni 1116–1128">{{Cite journal|last=Kulkarni|first=Chinmay|last2=Cambre|first2=Julia|last3=Kotturi|first3=Yasmine|last4=Bernstein|first4=Michael S.|last5=Klemmer|first5=Scott R.|date=1 January 2015|title=Talkabout: Making Distance Matter with Small Groups in Massive Classes|url=http://doi.acm.org/10.1145/2675133.2675166|journal=Proceedings of the 18th ACM Conference on Computer Supported Cooperative Work & Social Computing|series=CSCW '15|location=New York, NY, USA|publisher=ACM|pages=1116–1128|doi=10.1145/2675133.2675166|isbn=9781450329224}}</ref> Active participation in MOOC discussion forums has been found to improve students grades, their engagement, and leads to lower dropout rates,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=P.|first=Wang, Xu{{!}}Yang, Diyi{{!}}Wen, Miaomiao{{!}}Koedinger, Kenneth{{!}}Rosé, Carolyn|title=Investigating How Student's Cognitive Behavior in MOOC Discussion Forums Affect Learning Gains.|url=https://eric.ed.gov/?id=ED560568|journal=International Educational Data Mining Society|language=en}}</ref> however, ELLs are more likely to be spectators than active contributors in discussion forums.<ref name="Kulkarni 1116–1128"/> 
Researching studies show a “complex mix of affective, socio-cultural, and educational factors” that are inhibitors to their active participation in discussion forums.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Jackson|first=Jane|date=1 March 2002|title=Reticence in second language case discussions: anxiety and aspirations|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0346251X01000513|journal=System|volume=30|issue=1|pages=65–84|doi=10.1016/S0346-251X(01)00051-3}}</ref> As expected, English as the language of communication poses both linguistic and cultural challenges for ELLs, and they may not be confident in their English language communication abilities.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=T. Kanti Srikantaiah|last2=Dong Xiaoying|date=1 September 1998|title=The Internet and its impact on developing countries: examples from China and India|url=http://www.emeraldinsight.com/doi/abs/10.1108/10176749810237626|journal=Asian Libraries|volume=7|issue=9|pages=199–209|doi=10.1108/10176749810237626|issn=1017-6748}}</ref> Discussion forums may also be an uncomfortable means of communication especially for ELLs from Confucian cultures, where disagreement and arguing one’s points are often viewed as confrontational, and harmony is promoted.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Communication Between Cultures|last=Samovar|first=Larry A.|last2=Porter|first2=Richard E.|last3=McDaniel|first3=Edwin R.|last4=Roy|first4=Carolyn Sexton|date=7 February 2012|publisher=Wadsworth Publishing|isbn=9781111349103|edition=8|language=English}}</ref> Therefore, while ELLs may be perceived as being uninterested in participating, research studies show that they do not show the same hesitation in face to face discourse.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Holmes|first=Prue|date=1 October 2005|title=Ethnic Chinese Students’ Communication with Cultural Others in a New Zealand University This paper was first presented at the Australia New Zealand Communication Association (ANZCA) conference at Coolangatta, Queensland, Australia, in July 2002. The work is based on the author's doctoral thesis.|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/03634520500442160|journal=Communication Education|volume=54|issue=4|pages=289–311|doi=10.1080/03634520500442160|issn=0363-4523}}</ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Warden|first=C. A.|date=23 November 2016|title=Cultural Values and Communication Online: Chinese and Southeast Asian Students in a Taiwan International MBA Class|url=http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.1177/1080569905276669|journal=Business Communication Quarterly|language=en|volume=68|issue=2|pages=222–232|doi=10.1177/1080569905276669}}</ref> Finally, ELLs may come from high power distance cultures,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hofstede|first=Geert|date=1 January 2011|title=Dimensionalizing Cultures: The Hofstede Model in Context|url=http://scholarworks.gvsu.edu/orpc/vol2/iss1/8/?&sa=U&ei=9owuVLrgCIfXaqzngIgJ&ved=0CEsQFjAJ&usg=AFQjCNFBrStE0AJaAVPLrpU8s-lDqibYvw|journal=Online Readings in Psychology and Culture|language=en|volume=2|issue=1|doi=10.9707/2307-0919.1014|issn=2307-0919}}</ref> where teachers are regarded as authority figures, and the culture of back and forth conversations between teachers and students are not a cultural norm.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":3" /> As a result, discussion forums with active participation from the instructors may cause discomfort and prevent participation for students from such cultures.
== See also == * [[Language MOOC]] * [[Outcome-based education]] * [[OpenCourseWare]] * [[Saylor Foundation]] * [[Small private online course]] * [[Qualifications framework#Qualifications frameworks for online learning|Qualifications frameworks for online learning]] * [[Open educational resources in Canada]]
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}
== Sources == * {{Free-content attribution | title = Making Sense of MOOCs: A Guide for Policy-Makers in Developing Countries | author = Patru, Mariana; Balaji, Venkataraman | publisher = UNESCO | page numbers = 17–18, 21–22, 24 | source = UNESCO | documentURL = http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0024/002451/245122E.pdf | license statement URL = http://www.unesco.org/ulis/cgi-bin/ulis.pl?catno=245122&set=0058D2750B_1_34&gp=1&lin=1&ll=1 | license = CC-BY-SA IGO 3.0 }}
== Further reading == {{Commons category|Massive Open Online Course}} * {{cite book|last=Walsh|first=Taylor|title=Unlocking the Gates: How and Why Leading Universities Are Opening Up Access to Their Courses|publisher=Princeton University Press|year=2011|isbn=978-0-691-14874-8}}
{{MOOC}}
{{Open access navbox}}

revision.comment: Moving from [[Category:University of Western Sydney alumni]] to [[Category:Western Sydney University alumni]] per [[WP:CFDS]] using [[c:Help:Cat-a-lot|Cat-a-lot]]
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2016}} {{Use Australian English|date=November 2016}} '''Matthew Robert Glozier''' (born 1972 {{Citation needed|date=January 2010}}) is an Australian-based historian and history teacher.
==Early life and education==
Glozier was born in [[Sydney, Australia]], in 1972. He attended the [[University of Sydney]] and obtained a BA (Hons) degree (1990–93) and an [[MPhil]] in History (1997). He was awarded a Commonwealth Research Scholarship to complete a PhD at the [[University of Western Sydney]], entitled Scottish Soldiers in France and The Netherlands, 1660–1692 (conferred 2002).
==Academic career== Glozier has written works on expatriate soldier groups of French [[Huguenot]] and Scottish extraction. As Official Historian of the [[Australian Air Force Cadets]] he is currently preparing for publication a history of Australian Air Force cadets, 1941-2016, for the 75th anniversary diamond jubilee of the AAFC. He is also slowly compiling a volume of biographical reference relating to French refugee soldiers serving in armies across Europe circa 1685–1713. The project grew out of his earlier [[prosopography|prosopographical]] research into the Huguenot military support lent to [[William III of England|William of Orange]] during the Glorious Revolution of 1688. This is the subject of his monograph, published by Sussex Academic Press in 2002. A second book, ''Scottish Soldiers in France in the Reign of the Sun King: Nursery for Men of Honour History of Warfare'': 24 (Brill Academic Publishers), based on his doctoral thesis, appeared in 2004.
He has written and revised nine articles for the [[Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]] and his most recent biography is the first scholarly long study of [[Frederick Schomberg, 1st Duke of Schomberg|Friedrich Hermann von Schomberg]] to be written in English based on new research:<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sussex-academic.co.uk/sa/titles/history/glozierSchomberg.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-11-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070401234149/http://www.sussex-academic.co.uk/sa/titles/history/glozierSchomberg.htm |archivedate=1 April 2007 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> ''Marshal Schomberg, 1615–1690: ‘the ablest soldier of his age’: International soldiering and the formation of state armies in seventeenth–century Europe'' (Sussex Academic Press, 2005). The book has been called an "accessible study" that should "do much to rescue its subject's life and career from undeserved neglect".<ref>http://www.britannica.com/bps/additionalcontent/18/27866933/Marshal-Schomberg-16151690-The-Ablest-Soldier-of-His-Age-international-Soldiering-and-the-Formation-of-State-Armies-in-SeventeenthCentury-Europe</ref>
Glozier’s most recent work is a book on Huguenot [[soldiers]] in armies across Europe, co-edited with Dr David Onnekink (Utrecht University) – ''War, religion and service: Huguenot soldiering, 1685–1713'' (Ashgate Academic Publishers, 2007). A foreword to the book was contributed by [[Peter de la Billière]] who claimed ‘it is the first study of its kind to treat consistently the military contribution made by the Huguenots to armies outside France at the high point of their historical importance as a historical group.’.<ref>pp. xiv, Glozier & Onnekink (eds), ''War, religion and service: Huguenot soldiering, 1685–1713. Politics and Culture in North-West Europe 1650-1720.'' Aldershot: Ashgate Academic Publishers, 2007.</ref> The collection deals with areas of Huguenot studies often neglected by Anglophone research.
Glozier is widely published as a [[military historian]], interested in military, social and religious aspects; he analyses migration streams and the social and religious stratification of soldier [[refugee]] groups, in volumes that appeal to academic and to interested general readers<ref>http://repositories.tdl.org/tdl/handle/2249.1/5160</ref><ref>http://www.ashgate.com/default.aspx?page=637&calctitle=1&pageSubject=3672&pagecount=1&title_id=6914&edition_id=8873</ref> and whose international scope is useful for those seeking to explore the nexus of British and European military and political history.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sussex-academic.co.uk/sa/titles/history/glozier.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-11-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20070330102444/http://www.sussex-academic.co.uk/sa/titles/history/glozier.htm |archivedate=30 March 2007 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> He explores the rise of [[nationalism]], the transition from contract-based military service to the reliance on standing forces, and [[religion]] as a chief motivation for many soldiers.
Matthew is a co–founder of the Huguenot Society of Australia (begun in 2002) and a Fellow of the Huguenot Society of Great Britain and Ireland. He was made a Fellow of the Royal Historical Society in 2009. He was appointed Official Historian of the Australian Air Force Cadets organization in 2013. Matthew is an Honorary Associate of the Medieval and Early Modern Studies Centre (University of Sydney), President of the Sydney Society for Scottish History, and a History Master at Sydney Grammar School.
==Personal life== Matthew is married to Francesca and they have two children, Max and Charlotte. He coaches and writes about [[fencing]], a sport he has enjoyed since he was at school. He is currently researching Classical Fencing. {{Citation needed|date=October 2011}} He is a volunteer Officer of Cadets in the Australian Air Force Cadets and an enthusiastic owner of German Shorthaired Pointer dogs.
==Publications==
===Books===
*''Sydney Grammar School and the South African War, 1899-1902.'' Raleigh, NC: M. R. Glozier, Pending. Pp. xvi, 286. ISBN , 978-1-326-53370-0 *''75 Years Aloft: Australian Air Force Cadets (Royal Australian Air Force Air Training Corps), 1941-2016.'' Canberra: Defence Printing Service, 2016. Pp. xx, 428. {{ISBN|978-1-326-14299-5}} *''Marshal Schomberg, 1615–1690: the ablest soldier of his age: international soldiering and the formation of state armies in seventeenth–century Europe.'' Brighton, Portland: Sussex Academic Press, 2005. Pp. xiv, 249. {{ISBN|1-903900-60-3}} *''Scottish soldiers in France in the reign of the Sun King: nursery for men of honour.'' History of Warfare Series: 24. Leiden, Boston, Köln: E. J. Brill, 2004. Pp. xvi, 290. {{ISBN|90-04-13865-X}} *''The Huguenot soldiers of William of Orange and the Glorious Revolution of 1688: the lions of Judah.'' Brighton, Portland: Sussex Academic Press, 2002. Pp. xi, 240. {{ISBN|1-902210-82-4}} *with David Onnekink (eds), ''War, religion and service: Huguenot soldiering, 1685–1713. Politics and Culture in North-West Europe 1650-1720.'' Aldershot: Ashgate Academic Publishers, 2007. Pp. xvi, 316. {{ISBN|0-7546-5444-3}}
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.arts.usyd.edu.au/departs/medieval/index.php?page=staff&id=matthew.glozier Dr Matthew Glozier, Centre For Medieval Studies Faculty of Arts University of Sydney ]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} *[http://www.awm.gov.au/histories/peacekeeping/staff/index.asp ] *[http://www.aafc.org.au/who-we-are/75th-anniversary-official-history/ ]
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Glozier, Matthew Robert}} [[Category:University of Sydney alumni]] [[Category:Australian historians]] [[Category:Australian military historians]] [[Category:Historians of Europe]] [[Category:Australian people of Scottish descent]] [[Category:History teachers]] [[Category:1972 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Western Sydney University alumni]]

{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Mickey Mehta | image = Mickey Mehta.jpg | image_size = 150px | caption = Mickey Mehta attending a wellness seminar | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1962|08|29}} | birth_place = [[Mumbai]], Maharashtra | other_names = | known_for = Holistic health guru, yogic guru, equipment-free Yo workouts, health, and fitness coach | occupation = Holistic health and wellness guru | nationality = Indian }}
'''Mickey Mehta''' (born 29 August 1962) is an Indian holistic health, well-being, wellness, and fitness guru.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-08-29/people/33451402_1_wellness-health-sciences-fitness|title=Holistic guru Mickey Mehta celebrates 30 at 50|work=The Times of India|accessdate=26 October 2015}}</ref><ref name="mickeymehtahbf.com">{{cite web | url=http://www.mickeymehtahbf.com/about-mickey-mehta/ | title=Holistic Health Guru, Holistic Health and Wellness – Mickey Mehta | access-date=23 April 2016}}</ref> He is a TV and radio presenter (94.3 Radio One Mumbai and Delhi) and a columnist in various publications and websites.<ref>{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8GuvoQ4JjhM|title=Mickey Mehta with Rj Hrishi Kay on Radion One 94.3 Fm - 29th June'12|date=10 July 2012|work=YouTube|accessdate=26 October 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Xo0-MEk0K2o&list=PL647BADD4C87A224F|title=Reebok 'FIT in 15' Ep. 9|date=13 January 2011|work=YouTube|accessdate=26 October 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.magnamags.com/savvy/fitness-savvy-mickey-mehta-s-easy-office-workouts/572|title=FITNESS SAVVY: Mickey Mehta’s easy office workouts : MagnaMags|work=magnamags.com|accessdate=26 October 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.medimanage.com/my-weight/articles/mickey-mehtas-message-to-the-young-executive.aspx|title=Interview with Holistic Health Guru- Mickey Mehta|work=medimanage.com|accessdate=26 October 2015}}</ref> He preaches the concept of holistic health and equipment free workouts and has done so by establishing a chain of Mickey Mehta Wellness Temples across Mumbai city.<ref name="mickeymehtahbf.com1">{{cite web|url=http://www.mickeymehtahbf.com/contact-us.php|title=Fitness Centre in Mumbai, Wellness Centres|work=Free Diet Plans, Health Tips, Yoga, Holistic Health Guru|accessdate=26 October 2015}}</ref> The media often refer to Mickey Mehta as 'India's Leading Holistic Health Guru'.{{Citation needed|date=January 2016}} Mehta also aspires to build the largest social media base across as many platforms possible, to reach out to his audience.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://idiva.com/opinion-health/easy-and-effective-excercies-on-the-go/32334|title=Easy and Effective excercies on the go - Health|work=iDiva.com|accessdate=26 October 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/authors/mickey-mehta|title=Mickey Mehta|work=dna|accessdate=26 October 2015}}</ref> Mehta launches Yo workouts and Wellfie along with the ''Times of India'' at Marine Drive at the event of Yoga By The Bay.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://m.timesofindia.com/city/mumbai/Women-can-de-stress-tone-up-with-special-routine-at-Yoga-by-the-Bay-this-Sunday/articleshow/49952557.cms|title=Women can de-stress, tone up with special routine at Yoga by the Bay this Sunday|work=The Times of India|accessdate=26 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/mumbai/Hundreds-bend-stretch-during-Yoga-by-the-Bay/articleshow/48230193.cms|title=Hundreds bend & stretch during Yoga by the Bay|work=The Times of India|accessdate=5 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/mumbai/Its-Yoga-by-the-Bay-at-Marine-Drive-today/articleshow/48220560.cms|title=It’s Yoga by the Bay at Marine Drive today|work=The Times of India|accessdate=5 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://epaperbeta.timesofindia.com/Article.aspx?eid=31804&articlexml=Yoga-by-the-Bay-returns-this-Sunday-28082015006028|title=Yoga by the Bay returns this Sunday|publisher=|accessdate=5 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://m.timesofindia.com/city/mumbai/Yoga-by-the-Bay-returns-this-weekend-with-a-special-fitness-routine-for-elderly/articleshow/49197707.cms|title=Yoga by the Bay returns this weekend, with a special fitness routine for elderly|work=The Times of India|access-date=5 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://m.timesofindia.com/city/mumbai/Some-in-shorts-some-in-dhotis-elderly-throng-Yoga-by-the-Bay/articleshow/49219226.cms|title=Some in shorts & some in dhotis, elderly throng Yoga by the Bay|work=The Times of India|accessdate=5 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://m.timesofindia.com/city/mumbai/At-Yoga-by-the-Bay-asanas-for-every-age/articleshow/49487999.cms|title=At Yoga by the Bay, asanas for every age|work=The Times of India|accessdate=5 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://m.timesofindia.com/city/mumbai/Senior-citizens-to-stretch-it-out-at-Yoga-by-the-Bay-this-Sunday/articleshow/49510436.cms|title=Senior citizens to stretch it out at Yoga by the Bay this Sunday|work=The Times of India|accessdate=5 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://m.timesofindia.com/city/mumbai/Senior-citizens-show-their-yoga-moves-by-the-bay/articleshow/49530900.cms|title=Senior citizens show their yoga moves by the bay|work=The Times of India|accessdate=5 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://epaperbeta.timesofindia.com/Article.aspx?eid=31804&articlexml=Yoga-by-the-Bay-focuses-on-little-champs-29012016010047|title=Yoga by the Bay focuses on little champs this weekend|author=|date=|work=timesofindia.com|accessdate=23 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://m.timesofindia.com/city/mumbai/To-cool-their-nerves-and-de-stress-500-men-in-khaki-to-line-up-for-Yoga-by-the-Bay/articleshow/50316800.cms|title=To cool their nerves and de-stress, 500 men in khaki to line up for Yoga by the Bay|author=|date=|work=The Times of India|accessdate=23 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://m.timesofindia.com/city/mumbai/Women-can-de-stress-tone-up-with-special-routine-at-Yoga-by-the-Bay-this-Sunday/articleshow/49952557.cms|title=Women can de-stress, tone up with special routine at Yoga by the Bay this Sunday|author=|date=|work=The Times of India|accessdate=23 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://m.timesofindia.com/city/mumbai/Hundreds-turn-up-for-womens-special-edition-of-Yoga-by-the-Bay/articleshow/49976158.cms|title=Hundreds turn up for women's special edition of Yoga by the Bay|author=|date=|work=The Times of India|accessdate=23 April 2016}}</ref>
== Personal life == Mehta is from a middle-class [[Parsi]] family. His father and mother worked as a banker and secretary respectively and resided at [[Grant Road]], [[Mumbai]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mid-day.com/articles/from-grant-road-to-grand-success/178928|title=From Grant Road to grand success!|date=28 August 2012|work=mid-day|accessdate=26 October 2015}}</ref> He graduated from [[Bhonsala Military School]] at [[Nashik]], Maharashtra, [[India]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boystown.in|title=Welcome to Boys' Town School & Jr. College - Nashik|work=boystown.in|accessdate=26 October 2015}}</ref> and barely attended college due to his inclination towards the wellness and wellbeing segment. Mehta continues to coach his clients with regards to overall wellbeing and a healthy lifestyle.<ref name="mickeymehtahbf.com"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://epaper.timesofindia.com/Repository/getFiles.asp?Style=OliveXLib:LowLevelEntityToPrint_TOINEW&Type=text/html&Locale=english-skin-custom&Path=TOIBG/2010/02/07&ID=Pc04808|title=Mickey Mehta, holistic fitness expert While I advise my clients on fitness, incorporating Ayurveda and the wisdom of the Vedas, my own health is closely monitored by Ayurvedic grandmaster Dr Omkar Bilgi. For the last three years, he has monitored my diet and used massages and herbs to help me in my goal of retaining lifelong vigour and vitality. When I exercise, I take the help of yoga grandmasters to help me stretch, and offer me tips. My aim is to be as healthy as BK Iyengar is at 90.|work=timesofindia.com|accessdate=26 October 2015}}</ref> [[File:Mickey Mehta Dna iCan.jpg|thumb|right|Mickey Mehta (right) and [[Abhishek Bachchan]] (left) at the Dna iCan Women's Marathon held at Bandra Kurla Complex on 9 March 2014<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dnaican.com|title=dna ICAN - dna|publisher=|accessdate=26 December 2015}}</ref>]] [[File:Mickey Mehta interviewing Jaggi Vasudev at the Palladium Hotel in Lower Parel, Mumbai.jpg|thumb|right|Mickey Mehta interviewing [[Jaggi Vasudev]] at the Palladium Hotel, Mumbai on 29 March 2014<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mickeymehtahbf.wordpress.com/2014/04/22/mickey-mehta-interviewing-in-an-in-depth-conversation-with-sadhguru-jaggi-vasudeva/|title=MICKEY MEHTA – Interviewing & in an in-depth conversation with Sadhguru Jaggi Vasudeva - MICKEY MEHTA'S Blog|work=MICKEY MEHTA'S Blog|accessdate=26 October 2015}}</ref>]] [[File:Mickey Mehta guiding doctors on overall wellness at the Nair Dental College.jpg|thumb|left|Mickey Mehta addressed doctors on the subject of 'Medicine Cures, Nature heals' at the Nair Dental College on 7 April 2014<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tnmcnair.com|title=TNMC & Nair ch. Hospital|work=tnmcnair.com|accessdate=26 October 2015}}</ref>]]
== Career == He began his career as a black-belt martial arts instructor in 1983<ref name="idiva.com">{{cite web|url=http://idiva.com/experts-health/mickey-mehta/24|title=Women's Beauty, Style, Fitness, Entertainment, Lifestyle, Relationships, Careers - iDiva.com|work=iDiva.com|accessdate=26 October 2015}}</ref><ref name="photo-gallery">{{cite web|url=http://www.mickeymehtahbf.com/about-mickey-mehta/photo-gallery/|title=Photo Gallery|work=Free Diet Plans, Health Tips, Yoga, Holistic Health Guru|accessdate=13 January 2016}}</ref><ref name="press-snippets">{{cite web|url=http://www.mickeymehtahbf.com/about-mickey-mehta/press-snippets/|title=Press Snippets|work=Free Diet Plans, Health Tips, Yoga, Holistic Health Guru|accessdate=13 January 2016}}</ref><ref>Newspaper – 'Afternoon' – 30 March 2011</ref> and simultaneously worked as a personal trainer and a door-to-door masseur. His next recruitment was in 1984 at Ramada Plaza Palm Grove, a property of [[Ramada International]] chain of hotels<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ramadaplaza-juhu.com/index.asp|title=Ramada Plaza Palm Grove Five Star Business Hotels in Mumbai Juhu India|author=Ramada Plaza Palm Grove|work=ramadaplaza-juhu.com|accessdate=26 October 2015}}</ref> as a health club manager, followed by his employment at The [[Holiday Inn]], Muscat-Al Madinah, [[Oman]] with a similar job profile. Thereafter, he returned to [[Mumbai]] to become a health club manager for The [[Oberoi Trident]] at [[Nariman Point]], where he worked for five years. He started his solo career in 1993 and launched the 'Learn Swimming in 24 hours' programme which received press coverage and found its way to ''The Limca Book of World Records – 1995''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arabianbusiness.com/press_releases/detail/45947|title=Mickey Mehta plans to launch region’s first 360° Wellness Center in UAE|publisher=|accessdate=26 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mickeymehtahbf.com/about-mickey-mehta/|title=Holistic Health Guru, Holistic Health and Wellness – Mickey Mehta|work=Free Diet Plans, Health Tips, Yoga, Holistic Health Guru|accessdate=13 January 2016}}</ref> He moved on to practice holistic health and wellbeing, contributing to publications such as [[The Times of India]] Group,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/life-style/health-fitness/diet/How-often-should-you-eat/articleshow/15616282.cms|title=How often should you eat?|work=The Times of India|accessdate=26 October 2015}}</ref> [[Mid Day]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mid-day.com/articles/evoking-intellectual-discovery/190657|title=Evoking intellectual discovery|date=28 November 2012|work=mid-day|accessdate=26 October 2015}}</ref> [[The Asian Age]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asianage.com/life-and-style/burn-fat-sexciting-workouts-474|title=Burn the fat with sexciting workouts|work=The Asian Age|accessdate=26 October 2015}}</ref><ref>ASIAN AGE, 12 December 2005</ref> [[GQ]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gqindia.com/content/free-your-mind-and-body-follows|title=Free your mind, and the body follows|date=23 May 2011|work=GQ India|accessdate=26 October 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gqindia.com/content/mickey-mehta-360 |title=Page not found - GQ India |work=GQ India |access-date=26 December 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140305124536/http://www.gqindia.com/content/mickey-mehta-360 |archivedate=5 March 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/bollywood/aamir-to-ranbir-bollywood-boys-are-bulking-up-for-new-roles/article1-1331225.aspx|title=Aamir to Ranbir: Bollywood boys are bulking up for new roles|work=www.hindustantimes.com|accessdate=26 October 2015}}</ref> [[Afternoon DC]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.afternoondc.in/epaper/EpaperPost.aspx?id=135006|title=Today’s superwomen are adept at multitasking|work=afternoondc.in|accessdate=26 October 2015}}</ref> and ''Savvy'' (women's magazine).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.magnamags.com/savvy/fitness-savvy-mickey-mehta-on-meditating-to-shape-up/1357|title=FITNESS SAVVY: MICKEY MEHTA ON MEDITATING TO SHAPE UP : MagnaMags|work=magnamags.com|accessdate=26 October 2015}}</ref> He was featured in the ''Smart People Magazine'' where he spoke about holistic health and wellness representing the 'World Health Day'.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.smartpeople.co/full-magazine/|title=Full Magazine|work=Smart People|accessdate=26 October 2015}}</ref> In 1993, he was assigned to serve as a coach for [[Femina Miss India]]<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.mickeymehtahbf.com/about-mickey-mehta/making-winners/femina-miss-india-pageant/ | title=Femina Miss India Pageant | access-date=23 April 2016}}</ref> and also started off as a wellness coach for media barons, the [[Bollywood]] industry and industrialists.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gulfnews.com/life-style/food/celebrity-health-gurus-spill-trade-secrets-1.1053293|title=Celebrity health gurus spill trade secrets|author=Manjusha Radhakrishnan, Senior Reporter|work=gulfnews.com|accessdate=26 October 2015}}</ref> In 2003 he inaugurated Mickey Mehta’s 360 degree Gyms which are promoted as wellness temples. The first branch was established at [[Hughes Road]], [[Mumbai]], in April 2003.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asklaila.com/listing/Mumbai/Grant+Road/Mickey+Mehta+Health+Club/0pUjMpPm/|title=Mickey Mehta Health Club|work=asklaila|accessdate=26 October 2015}}</ref> The brand later expanded to 12 wellness temples that include facilities such as swimming and equipment-free training such as [[yoga]], breathing exercises, [[meditation]], [[chant]]ing, [[Training camp|boot camp]], [[calisthenics]], [[aerobics]], [[agility drill]]s and lifestyle counselling.<ref name="mickeymehtahbf.com1"/> Mehta's centres are known for providing a discount that is equal to his age during August and September every year. The seasonal offer is always promoted as 'Mickey Mehta's Birthday Offer'.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.onlineprnews.com/news/413853-1377697543-mickey-mehta-kick-starts-next-halfcentury-with-wellness.html|title=Mickey Mehta Kick Starts Next Half-Century With ‘Wellness’|work=onlineprnews.com|accessdate=26 October 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://mumbai.quikr.com/Get-52-Off-on-Annual-Membership-at-Mickey-Mehta-s-Gym-W0QQAdIdZ178996846 |title=Archived ==Heal the World Initiative==
===2011=== He launched ''Heal the World Initiative'' on 24 August 2011. Established by Mickey Mehta to highlight public focus towards social contribution, the initiative was launched with a tag line 'Each One to Reach One'. On 3 October 2011, the initiative commenced with an attempt to empower the destitute, where Mickey Mehta initiated a training course for the women at the NGO SMILE, to help them become Yoga Instructors, so that they would be able to support their families monetarily.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.afternoondc.in/health-fitness/know-more-yoga-for-household-help/article_67052|title=Know more: Yoga for household help|work=afternoondc.in|accessdate=26 October 2015}}</ref>
===2012=== On 23 November 2012, one of the key initiatives undertaken by Mehta involved the training of [[Mumbai]]'s police. The police officers of [[Mumbai]] city began to be trained with psychological counselling, diet education and tips on exercise and yoga. The initiative exhibits no monetary interest and is an ongoing initiative till date.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.millenniumpost.in/NewsContent.aspx?NID=15841|title=Mumbai cops fight to win battle of bulge - Millennium Post|work=Millennium Post|accessdate=26 October 2015}}</ref>
===2013=== On 12 February 2013, Mehta launched a braille book with wellness tips for pregnant and lactating women. The book was launched in collaboration with the Director of National Association for the Blind and was titled ''Swasthya Aur Aarogya''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/entertainment/report-fitness-guru-mickey-mehta-educates-the-visually-impaired-1785373|title=Fitness guru Mickey Mehta educates the visually impaired|date=4 January 2013|work=dna|accessdate=26 October 2015}}</ref>
===2014=== On 15 February 2014, Mehta along with dress designer Maheka Mirpuri launched the MCan, a charitable foundation at the Tata Memorial hospital (TMH) for providing financial assistance to the underprivileged towards cure for cancer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/mumbai/Maheka-Mirpuri-with-Mickey-Mehta-to-provide-holistic-care-for-cancer-patients/articleshow/30532651.cms|title=Maheka Mirpuri with Mickey Mehta to provide holistic care for cancer patients|work=The Times of India|accessdate=26 October 2015}}</ref> Mickey Mehta initiated the launch of a dedicated health department called Wellness Temple at the Masina Hospital in Byculla (Mumbai) for the benefit of its patients. The launch took place on 5 June 2014.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.pharmabiz.com/NewsDetails.aspx?aid=82285&sid=2 | title=Mickey Mehta launches wellness temple at Masina Hospital | website=pharmabiz.com | date=5 June 2014 | access-date=26 December 2015}}</ref>

page.title: Ministry of Education and Skills Development

revision.text:
The '''Ministry of Tertiary Education Research, Science and Technology''' is a [[government ministry]] of [[Botswana]]. Its offices are in [[Gaborone]].<ref>"[http://www.mterst.gov.bw/index.php?id=15 Contact Us]." Ministry of Education and Skills Development. Retrieved 18 April 2013.</ref>
Collaboration, Co-production & Consuming.
==History== The Ministry was established in October 2016. Our primary mandate is to transform Botswana from a resource based to a knowledge based economy.
==Vision== A knowledge based society enabling prosperity for all.
==Mission== To provide and build knowledge and innovation through the development and implementation of Policy on Tertiary Education, Research, Science and Technology to transform Botswana into a knowledge - based society through effect stakeholder collaboration.
==Departments== * Corporate Services. * Radiation Protection Inspectorate. * Research, Science and Technology. * Tertiary Education Financing. * Teacher Training and Technical Education. * Botswana National Commission for UNESCO.
==Parastatals== * [[Botswana Accountancy College]] (BAC). * Botswana College of Open and Distance Learning (BOCODOL). * Botswana Innovation Hub. (BIH). * Botswana Institute for Technology, Research and Innovation (BITRI). * [[Botswana International University of Science and Technology]] (BIUST). * Botswana Qualifications Authority (BQA). * Human Resource Council (HRDC). * [[University of Botswana]] (UB).
==Institutions==
'''College of Education:''' * Molepolole College of Education. * Serowe College of Education. * Tlokweng College of Education. * Tonota College of Education.
'''Technical Colleges:''' * Botswana College of Engineering and Technology. * Gaborone Technical College. * Jwaneng Technical College. * Maun Technical College. * Oodi College of Applied Arts and Technology. * Palapye Technical College. * Selebi Phikwe Technical College. * Francistown College of Technical and Vocational Education.
==See also== {{portal|Botswana|Education|Politics}} * [[Education in Botswana]] {{clear}}
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * {{URL|www.moe.gov.bw}},{{dead link|date=May 2016}} the ministry's official website
